conclusion: Analyze forces on object A and deformation of springs B and C.
Initial conditions: mass of A is 2 kg, spring constant of B is 200 N/m, spring constant of C is unknown, distance ab is 0.6 m.
Initially, tension in spring B balances weight of A: k1 x1 = mg.
Final conditions: tension force of spring B on A equals gravitational force of A.
At final position, k1 x2 = mg, A is in equilibrium.
Deformation of spring C is given by distance ab: ΔxC = 0.6 m.
Force exerted by spring C is FC = k2 ΔxC.
Equilibrium condition: mg = k1 x2 + FC, but k1 x2 = mg implies FC = 0.
Consider deformation of spring B due to force from spring C.
Height rise of A is difference between initial and final compressions of spring B: Δh = x1 - x2.
Calculate initial compression: x1 = mg/k1 = 0.098 m.
Calculate final compression: x2 = mg/k1 = 0.098 m.
Since x1 = x2, height rise Δh = 0.
Calculate stiffness coefficient k2: k2 = 19.6/0.6 = 32.67 N/m.
Final answer: height rise of A is 0 m, stiffness coefficient k2 is 32.67 N/m.
